lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read and understand a text containing the units' target language.
supportStrategies: (Reading) Before reading, write 3–4 key vocabulary items from recent units on the board. Students scan the text and circle the words they find.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen and identify the units' target language correctly.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Play short chunks of the review audio. After each, ask: “What word did you hear?” Students point to matching picture or write it down.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can reflect on their learning across the units and say what they can do. "I can say colours. I know toys..."
supportStrategies: (Reflection) Draw a mind map on the board with topics (e.g., food, transport, school). Students suggest words or sentences they remember for each.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
